Chapter 364: Concerning the Knowledge of the Station of Two Secrets, the Attainment of Repose in This World and the Hereafter by Him Who Knows Them, and the Divine Jealousy (الغيرة الإلهية).

If a person stands up for judgments (aḥkām) on behalf of another, that one is the deputy (al-mustanāb).
But if he was not deputized, yet stands up for them, he has neither doubt nor uncertainty.
And if he were to pray against him who transgresses, his prayer concerning him would be answered.
Due to the truthfulness of the promise and the sincerity (al-ikhlāṣ) within it, he strikes when he wills, and is not struck.

[Everything has always been with Allah in Actuality (bi-l-fi‘l) concerning His servants; nothing is with Him in Potentiality (bi-l-quwwa)]

This station (manzil) is the Divine glad tidings (al-bushrā al-ilāhiyya) of the repose (al-rāḥa) necessitated by the Divine solicitude (al-i‘tinā’ al-ilāhī) for those righteous servants of Allah who are given these tidings, until the Day of Resurrection and in the Resurrection. For everything has always been with Allah in Actuality (bi-l-fi‘l) concerning His servants; nothing is with Him in Potentiality (bi-l-quwwa). Thus, the Divine definitions (al-ta‘rīfāt al-ilāhiyya) came to him concerning what Allah had in it of Acts (al-af‘āl) and States (al-aḥwāl), so that he might recall with his intellect his witnessing (shuhūd) of that from his Lord within himself, during his state of non-existence, due to the Fixity (al-thubūt) upon which he was, which necessitated his acceptance of the Divine disposal (al-taṣarruf al-ilāhī) within him.

And by that Fixed State (al-ḥāla al-thubūtiyya), he complied with the command of the Real (al-Ḥaqq) for creation (al-takwīn), for the command is only directed toward one characterized by hearing (al-sam‘). The Divine Word (al-qawl al-ilāhī) has always been, and the Fixed Hearing (al-sam‘ al-thubūtī) has always been. What came into existence (ḥadatha) was only the Existential Hearing (al-sam‘ al-wujūdī), which is a branch of the Fixed Hearing. Thus, the state transferred onto the essence (ayn) of the hearing, but the hearing itself did not transfer, for the essences (al-a‘yān) do not change from one state to another. Rather, the states clothe them with judgments (aḥkām), and they are clothed, leading the ignorant to imagine that the essence has transferred. The states seek the Divine Names (al-asmā’ al-ilāhiyya), not that the essences are described as seeking. New names and a heart (al-qalb) arise for the essences according to the judgments of the states upon which they revolve. Were it not for the states, the essences would not be distinguished, for there is nothing there but a single essence (ayn wāḥida) distinguished by its Essence (dhāt) from the Necessary of Existence (wājib al-wujūd), just as it shares with Him the necessity of Fixity (wujūb al-thubūt). Thus, for Him (Exalted is He) is the necessity of Fixity and Existence (al-wujūd), and for this essence is the necessity of Fixity. The states for this essence are like the Divine Names for the Real (al-Ḥaqq). Just as the Names belong to the single Essence (al-ayn al-wāḥida) without multiplying or increasing the Named, so too the states for this essence do not multiply or increase it, despite the intelligibility of multiplicity (al-kathra) and number in the Names and the states. By this, it is valid to say of this essence that it is "upon the Image" (alā al-ṣūra), meaning upon the reality of the Divine Command. This essence attained perfection through Existence (al-wujūd), which is one of the states upon which it revolved. The only thing lacking from its perfection is the negation of the judgment of the necessity of Existence (wujūb al-wujūd), for the sake of distinction between it and Allah, since that cannot be lifted, nor can it establish a footing therein.

And He has another distinction: the Real (al-Ḥaqq) revolves *in* the states; the states do not revolve *upon* Him, because it is impossible for a state to have a judgment over the Real. Rather, He (Exalted is He) has judgment over them. Therefore, He revolves in them, and they do not revolve upon Him: <<كُلَّ يَوْمٍ هُوَ في شَأْنٍ>> (Every day He is in a [new] affair). For if they revolved upon Him, they would necessitate judgments upon Him. The essence of the world (ayn al-‘ālam) is not like that; the states revolve upon it, and their judgments appear therein, though their revolution upon it is by the hand of Allah (Exalted is He). As for the Real's revolving in the states, this is known through the descent (al-nuzūl), the establishment (al-istiwā’), the concomitance (al-ma‘iyya), the laughter, the joy, the pleasure, and the wrath. Every state by which the Real describes Himself, He (Glorified is He) revolves in it by judgment. This is the difference between us and the Real, and it is the clearest and most manifest of differences. Thus, participation occurred in the states, just as it occurred in the Names, because the Names are the names of the states, and their Named is the essence (al-‘ayn), just as they are Names for Him by a different proportion, and their Named is the Real (al-Ḥaqq). So, He is <<هُوَ السَّمِيعُ الْبَصِيرُ>> (He is the All-Hearing, the All-Seeing), the All-Knowing, the All-Powerful, and you are the hearing, the seeing, the knowing, the powerful. The state of hearing, sight, knowledge, and power is for us and for Him by two different proportions, for He is He, and we are we. We are instruments for Him, and He is instruments for us. For Allah said, upon the tongue of His servant, "Allah hears him who praises Him," and He said: <<فَأَجِرْهُ حَتَّى يَسْمَعَ كَلامَ الله>> (Grant him protection until he hears the Word of Allah), and <<وما رَمَيْتَ إِذْ رَمَيْتَ ولكِنَّ الله رَمى‏>> (And you did not throw when you threw, but Allah threw). The instrument (al-āla) was the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him).

The revolving of the Real in the states is for the manifestation of their essences (a‘yān), like the revolving of the One in the degrees of numbers for the manifestation of their essences. Know that this station (manzil) was only named the Station of Two Secrets (manzil sirrayn) because of a marvelous secret: that the single thing is doubled by itself, and not by another, in the sensible (al-maḥsūs) and the intelligible (al-ma‘qūl). As for the sensible: Adam was doubled by what was opened in his short left rib, the form of Eve (Ḥawwā’). He was one in his essence, then became a pair through her, yet she is nothing other than his own self, concerning which it was said that he is one. As for the intelligible: the Divinity (al-ulūhiyya) is nothing other than His Essence (dhāt), yet the intelligible concept of Divinity is contrary to the intelligible concept of His being an Essence. Thus, Divinity doubled the Essence of the Real, yet it is nothing other than its own essence. Just as He spread forth in the sensible realm from Adam and from what doubled him from his own essence, many men and women, upon the image of the pair, so too did He spread forth from the Essence of the Real (Exalted is He) and His being the God (Ilāh) of the world, upon the image of these two intelligible concepts. The world came forth upon the image of an effector (mu’aththir) and an affected (mu’aththar fīhi) for the sake of procreation (al-tawālud)—that is, the procreation of its parts. For Divinity is a judgment (ḥukm) for the Essence, by which it judged the creation of the world. When it preferred the judgment of creating the world for that purpose, the world appeared in the image of its Creator, between an effector and an affected, just as occurred in the sensible realm. For Allah did not create from Adam and Eve an earth, nor a heaven, nor a mountain, nor anything other than their own species; rather, He created from them only their like in form and judgment.

Indeed, She whose existence was the cause of Being (al-wujūd), is an Essence whose word sanctifies its meaning.
I surely love Her, and I love Her nearness to me, and I love everyone who loves Her.
Layla, Lubna, Rabab, and Zaynab are peers whose faces are brought to life by my love for Her.
If I die, Her existence dies with our death, for our existence is Her essence and Her other.
How wondrous is our case and Hers! For our existence is single (fard), there is no second, so who doubled it?

Since the Origin (al-aṣl) was one, and nothing doubled it except itself, and no multiplicity (kathra) appeared except from its essence, likewise, in everything in the world, there was a sign (āya) indicating that He is One. The entire cosmos (al-kawn) is body and spirit (rūḥ), by which the genesis of Existence (nash’at al-wujūd) is established. The world is to the Real (al-Ḥaqq) as the body is to the spirit. Just as the spirit is only known through the body—for when we looked into it and saw its form, while it remained, the judgments we witnessed from the body and its form, such as the perception of sensibles and meanings, departed from it—we knew that beyond the manifest body there is another meaning (ma‘nā) which granted it the judgments of perceptions therein. We named that meaning the spirit (rūḥ) of this body. Likewise, we did not know that we have a command (amr) that moves us, stills us, and judges in us as it wills, until we looked into our souls (nufūs). When we knew our souls, we knew our Lord, exactly like one sandal following another. For this reason, He informed us in the Revelation (al-waḥy) with His saying: "Whoever knows his self knows his Lord." And in the revealed Divine tradition (al-khabar al-munazzal al-ilāhī): <<سَنُرِيهِمْ آياتِنا في الْآفاقِ وفي أَنْفُسِهِمْ حَتَّى يَتَبَيَّنَ لَهُمْ أَنَّهُ الْحَقُّ>> (We shall show them Our signs in the horizons and in themselves, until it becomes clear to them that He is the Real).

The world only appeared from Allah in the image of the reality upon which the Command rests. There is no honor in the Origin (al-aṣl) for me from which evils (al-shurūr) are derived. The world is in the grasp of Pure Good (al-khayr al-maḥḍ), which is Complete Existence (al-wujūd al-tāmm). However, since the contingent (al-mumkin) has a view toward non-existence (al-‘adam), it is by that measure that evil is attributed to it. For it does not possess the judgment of the necessity of Existence (wujūb al-wujūd) by its own essence. If evil occurs to it, it is from that perspective, and it does not persist or become fixed, for it is in the grasp of Pure Good and Existence.

Furthermore, part of the complete Gnosis (al-ma‘rifa) established in the knowledge of Allah is that the body has intelligible and known effects in the spirit, due to the sciences of spiritual tastes (ulūm al-adhwāq) that can only be known through it. And the spirit has sensible effects in the body, witnessed by every living creature in itself. Likewise, concerning the world and the Real (al-Ḥaqq), Allah has manifest effects in it, which are the states in which the world revolves—and that is due to the judgment of His Name, Time (al-Dahr). The Real (Glorified is He) informed us that the world, in terms of what He has obligated it with, has effects that we would not have known had He not informed us of them. This is because if we follow His Messenger in what he brought us concerning obedience to Allah, He loves us and is pleased with us, and thus is pleased with us. If we disobey Him, fail to comply with His command, and rebel against Him, He informs us that we have displeased Him and angered Him, and thus He is wrathful toward us. If we supplicate Him, He answers us. Thus, supplication is from His effect, and the answer is from our effect. This is so that you may know that He only manifests something from the image of what He is. It is impossible for the matter to be otherwise, for where else could it come from? There is nothing there but Him.

A thing only gives what is in its potentiality. For this reason, the Real described Himself to us with attributes (nu‘ūt) that are contingent (muḥdathāt) in our view, yet in reality, they are His attributes that appeared in us, and then returned to Him. And He (Glorified is He) described us with attributes that His Majesty (jalāl) deserves, and thus they are truly His attributes. Were it not that He created us upon the image of what He is in Himself, it would not be valid or established for us to accept any attribute with which He described us that is rightfully His, nor would He accept any attribute with which He described Himself that is rightfully ours. Yet, all is rightfully His. He is the Origin (al-aṣl) of which we are the branch, and the Names are the branches of this tree—I mean the Tree of Existence (shajarat al-wujūd)—and we are the essence of the fruit. Rather, He is the essence of the fruit. We have no analogy except the existence of this tree.

Part of the complete Gnosis of Allah is what He informed us of through the tongue of His Messenger (peace and blessings be upon him) concerning His transformation (taḥawwul) in images (al-ṣuwar) in the stations of Theophany (mawāṭin al-tajallī). This is the origin of our own transformation in states (al-aḥwāl), inwardly and outwardly, and all of that is in Him (Exalted is He). Likewise, He (Exalted is He) is in the affairs (shu’ūn) of the world according to what the judicial arrangement (al-tartīb al-ḥukmī) necessitates. His affair tomorrow cannot be except tomorrow, and the affair of today cannot be except today, and the affair of yesterday cannot be except yesterday. This is all when viewed in relation to Him (Exalted is He). As for the view toward the affair itself, it could occur at a time other than when it does, had the Real (Exalted is He) willed it. There is no compulsion (jabr) or confusion in His Will (mashī’a)—Exalted is Allah far above that! Rather, His Will has only one single connection.

Among [the verses related to this station] is His saying: <<سَنَفْرُغُ لَكُمْ أَيُّهَ الثَّقَلانِ>> (We shall attend to you, O you two heavy burdens [al-thaqalān]). This means, [We shall attend] to you and to the world which is other than us. He only named us the two heavy burdens because of the heaviness (al-thiql) in us, which is the essence of our delay in existence (al-wujūd), so we were slow. It is the habit of the heavy to be slow, just as it is the habit of the light to be quick. We and the Jinn are the two heavy burdens, and we are heavier than the Jinn due to the element that predominates us, which is earth (al-turāb). The human is the last existent in the world, because an abbreviation (al-mukhtaṣar) is only abbreviated from an extended work (muṭawwal); otherwise, it is not an abbreviation. The world is the abbreviation of the Real, and the human is the abbreviation of the world and the Real. He is the purity of the abbreviation—I mean the Perfect Human (الإنسان الكامل). As for the animal human (al-insān al-ḥayawān), he is the abbreviation of the world. It is for him that the Real attends, to establish upon him the balance (mīzān) for which he was created.

His saying <<سَنَفْرُغُ لَكُمْ أَيُّهَ الثَّقَلانِ>> is a word of threat, and the Perfect Human is not addressed by this speech. However, in this word there is an indication of the attachment of Mercy (al-raḥma) to them (the two heavy burdens), which is found in the opening (fatḥ) of the *lām* attached to the pronoun of the addressee (لَكُمْ). Although the Divine opening (al-fatḥ al-ilāhī) may be with what displeases, just as it may be with what pleases, His Mercy preceded His Wrath. The verse uses the instrument of the future (al-sīn, *sa-*), and the final degree of the future is the ultimate destiny of the world toward the Mercy that has no wrath after it, due to the lifting of obligation (al-taklīf) and the fulfillment of limits (al-ḥudūd). Since the address uses the pronoun of the addressee (لَكُمْ), and we know from the Divine Generosity (al-karam al-ilāhī) that He always prefers the side of the blessed (al-su‘adā’) and the side of Mercy over the opposite, for this reason, what the people of wretchedness (ahl al-shaqā’) suffer is called *‘adhāb* (punishment/torment), because the blessed find the pains of the wretched sweet (yasta‘dhibūn) out of preference for the Divine Presence (al-janāb al-Ḥaqq) when they associated partners with Him. Thus, they find bliss in the causes of pain. So the Real named that *‘adhāb* (torment) out of preference for them when they preferred Him. Therefore, the letter of address (ḥarf al-khiṭāb) was used, and the *lām* was opened, so that it might be known by the instrument of address that they are a specific people, because the pronoun of the absent (ḍamīr al-ghā’ib) is not missing from the world. Thus, He must have people [who are absent], like His saying concerning the blessed: <<لَهُمْ جَنَّاتٍ تَجْرِي>> (For them are Gardens beneath which rivers flow), where He used the pronoun of the absent, so they are absent from these addressees. The opening of the *lām* is an opening of mercy, which the contextual clues (qarā’in al-aḥwāl) grant.

This instrument has degrees by which the Real deals with His servants, such as His saying: <<وَإِنَّهُمْ عِنْدَنا لَمِنَ الْمُصْطَفَيْنَ الْأَخْيارِ>> (And indeed, they are with Us among the chosen, the best), and His saying: <<ما كانَ الله لِيَذَرَ الْمُؤْمِنِينَ عَلى‏ ما أَنْتُمْ عَلَيْهِ>> (Allah would not leave the believers upon the state in which you are), and <<وما كانَ الله لِيُضِيعَ إِيمانَكُمْ>> (Nor would Allah let your faith be lost), and <<وَسَخَّرَ لَكُمْ ما في السَّماواتِ وما في الْأَرْضِ>> (And He subjected to you whatever is in the heavens and whatever is in the earth), and <<وَخَلَقَ لَكُمْ ما في الْأَرْضِ>> (And He created for you whatever is on the earth), and <<وَلَهُ ما في السَّماواتِ وما في الْأَرْضِ وما بَيْنَهُما وما تَحْتَ الثَّرى‏>> (And to Him belongs whatever is in the heavens and whatever is in the earth and what is between them and what is beneath the moist earth). Thus, it is for Him and for us. Despite this, proper conduct (al-adab) is incumbent upon us. Through proper conduct, the people of authority become companions without familiarity (inbisāṭ), because witnessing (al-shuhūd) and familiarity do not combine. One of them said: "Sit upon the carpet (al-bisāṭ), but beware of familiarity (al-inbisāṭ)."

I have worshipped Him by a command that is not fitting for me, and I do not worship Him whom I describe by His image.
For He said this—I did not say it—and the form of my state is none other than His form.

For the lowliest of the low (al-dūn al-adwan), if an attribute not necessitated by his station is attributed to him, he recoils from it because it is a satire against him, just as the noble recoils from being described with less than what his nobility deserves.

(A Connection) [The Difference Between the Saint (al-Walī) and the Prophet (al-Nabī)]

As for those among our companions who said—and to which Imam Abū Ḥāmid al-Ghazālī and others subscribed—that the difference between the saint (al-walī) and the prophet (al-nabī) is the descent of the Angel (al-malak), such that the saint is inspired (mulham) while the prophet has the Angel descend upon him, even though the prophet is also inspired in some matters, being a synthesis of sainthood (al-wilāya) and prophecy (al-nubūwa)—this is an error in our view on the part of those who hold it, and evidence of their lack of spiritual taste (dhawq). The difference lies only in *what* the Angel brings down, not in the descent of the Angel itself. What the Angel brings down upon the Messenger (al-rasūl) and the Prophet is different from what the Angel brings down upon the following saint (al-walī al-tābi‘). For the Angel may descend upon the following saint, through his following, to give him understanding of what the Prophet brought, which this saint had not realized through knowledge, even if he is later in time—meaning, later than the time of the Prophet’s existence. The Angel may descend upon him to define the soundness or weakness of what the Prophet brought, concerning matters that have been fabricated against him, or which were mistakenly thought to be sound from him, or which were abandoned due to the weakness of the narrator while being sound in reality. The Angel may also descend upon him with glad tidings (al-bushrā) from Allah that he is among the people of felicity (ahl al-sa‘āda) and triumph, and with security (al-amān)—all of this in the life of this world. For Allah (Mighty and Majestic) says: <<لَهُمُ الْبُشْرى‏ في الْحَياةِ الدُّنْيا>> (For them are glad tidings in the life of this world). And He said concerning the people of uprightness (ahl al-istiqāma) who affirm the Lordship of Allah, that the angels descend upon them. The Exalted said: <<إِنَّ الَّذِينَ قالُوا رَبُّنَا الله ثُمَّ اسْتَقامُوا تَتَنَزَّلُ عَلَيْهِمُ الْمَلائِكَةُ أَلَّا تَخافُوا ولا تَحْزَنُوا وأَبْشِرُوا بِالْجَنَّةِ الَّتِي كُنْتُمْ تُوعَدُونَ نَحْنُ أَوْلِياؤُكُمْ في الْحَياةِ الدُّنْيا>> (Indeed, those who say, "Our Lord is Allah," and then remain upright, the angels will descend upon them, [saying], "Do not fear and do not grieve, but receive good tidings of the Paradise which you were promised. We are your protecting friends [awliyā’ukum] in the life of this world). Among the friends of Allah (awliyā’ Allāh) are those who have from Allah the spiritual taste (dhawq) of the descent (al-inzāl) in the revelation (al-tanzīl).

The error that occurred to those who hold the contrary view arose only from their belief in themselves that they had encompassed all paths and stations (al-maqāmāt) through their spiritual journeying, and that no station remained without them having a taste (dhawq) of it. Since they did not see an Angel descend upon them, they believed that this was exclusive to the Prophet. Their spiritual taste is sound, but their judgment is false. They hold that if one of them brings an addition [to knowledge], it is accepted from him because he is a trustworthy person of spiritual taste; they have no disparagement or criticism, and they do not transgress their own taste. It is from this point that the error occurred. Had the statement concerning the descent of the Angel upon the saint reached them from those who preceded them, or those who were contemporary with them among the People of Allah (ahl Allāh), they would have accepted it and not rejected it. We have seen in events that a group of predecessors did not affirm a certain matter, but when they heard it from us, they accepted it and did not deny it, due to the removal of suspicion concerning their peers and likes. If one of the People of Allah, who are the people of allusions (ahl al-ishārāt)—those who call out from the head of distance—were to say: "You have stated that there is no reality (ḥaqīqa) or proportion (nisba) in the world except that it originates from a Divine proportion, and among the proportions of the world is need (al-iftiqār). Abū Yazīd, who is one of the people of Unveiling (al-kashf) and Existence (al-wujūd), said that Allah told him in one of his witnessings with Him: 'Draw near to Me with what is not Mine: abasement (al-dhilla) and need (al-iftiqār).'"

[That the Real (Exalted is He) possesses Mercy, Pardon, Generosity, and Forgiveness]

Know, O seeker of benefit, that the Real (Exalted is He) possesses Mercy (al-raḥma), Pardon (al-‘afw), Generosity (al-karam), and Forgiveness (al-maghfira). These are among His Beautiful Names (al-asmā’ al-ḥusnā), and they are truly His (Exalted is He). Likewise, He possesses Retribution (al-intiqām) and Severe Punishment (al-baṭsh al-shadīd). He (Glorified is He) is the Merciful, the Pardoner, the Generous, the Forgiving, the Possessor of Retribution. It is impossible for the effects of these Names to be *in* Him, or for Him to be a locus for their effects. For Merciful toward whom? Pardoner of whom? Generous toward whom? Forgiving of whom? Possessor of Retribution against whom? One must say that Allah the Creator seeks the created, and the created seeks the Creator. The attribute of the seeker is known, and the attained does not negate. Thus, the world is necessary because the Divine Realities (al-ḥaqā’iq al-ilāhiyya) seek it. We have explained to you that the intelligibility of His being an Essence is not the intelligibility of His being a God (Ilāh). Thus, the rank (al-martaba) doubled. There is nothing in objective existence (al-wujūd al-‘aynī) except the essence (al-‘ayn). He, from the perspective of His Essence, is independent of the worlds (ghanī ‘an al-‘ālamīn). But from the perspective of the Beautiful Names, which seek the world due to its contingency (imkān) so that their effects may appear in it, He seeks the existence of the world. If the world were already existent, He would not seek its existence. The Names are like a family (al-‘ā’ila) to Him, and the master of the family strives for his dependents. The creation (al-khalq) is the more distant dependent, and the Names are the nearer family. The world asked Him for existence due to its contingency, and the Names asked Him for existence for the manifestation of their effects. And one only asks for what does not yet exist. Therefore, the existence of the world is necessary. The Book (al-kitāb) is the ruler, Knowledge (al-‘ilm) is prior, and the Will (al-mashī’a) is the confirmer. It is impossible for it not to occur.

The charge of disbelief (al-takfīr) fell upon the faction that said: <<إِنَّ الله فَقِيرٌ ونَحْنُ أَغْنِياءُ>> (Indeed, Allah is poor, and we are rich)—taken as a whole. For they are not rich (independent) of Allah, nor is the Real delayed in bringing them into existence or in showering blessings upon them, which is a favor and grace from Him, due to the judgment of a prior Book. Allah the Exalted said: <<لَوْ لا كِتابٌ من الله سَبَقَ لَمَسَّكُمْ فِيما أَخَذْتُمْ عَذابٌ>> (Had it not been for a decree [kitāb] from Allah that preceded, you would have been touched by a great punishment for what you took). Thus, the judgment belongs to the Book. The proportion of the Book is not the proportion of the Essence (al-dhāt). The determination of the execution of the judgment upon whom it is executed belongs to the Book, like the custodian (al-sādin) and the disposer by the judgment of the compulsion of the rank (jabr al-martaba). This is what the Realities (al-ḥaqā’iq) grant by themselves, and they do not change. If the Realities were to change, the order (al-niẓām) would be corrupted, and there would be no knowledge (‘ilm) at all, nor Real (Ḥaqq), nor creation (khalq).

If the rational person (al-‘āqil) were to look at the wisdom of the Divine address in His saying: <<سَنَكْتُبُ ما قالُوا>> (We shall record what they said), and took it from His saying: <<كَتَبَ رَبُّكُمْ عَلى‏ نَفْسِهِ الرَّحْمَةَ>> (Your Lord has decreed [kataba] upon Himself Mercy)—meaning, He made it incumbent upon Himself, because there is no obligator except Him (Exalted is He)—He said: We shall make incumbent what they said, concerning what returns as harm upon them. And He said at the end of the verse: <<وَنَقُولُ ذُوقُوا عَذابَ الْحَرِيقِ>> (And We shall say, "Taste the punishment of the Burning Fire") as a penalty for their saying. For this reason, the confirmation of their disbelief was based on the totality [of their statement], for they are not rich. This is the spirit (rūḥ) of this verse.

As for your argument concerning what He said to Abū Yazīd, that is also the essence of the totality. He did not say abasement (al-dhilla) alone, but said abasement *and* need (al-dhilla wa-l-iftiqār). The proportion of the totality is not the proportion of the individuals. Were it not for the contingent (al-mumkin), no effect of the Divine Names would appear. The Name is the Named itself, especially the Divine Names. Existence (al-wujūd) is the seeker and the sought, and the object of the seeking is non-existence (al-‘adam)—either the annihilation of an existent or the creation of a non-existent. Allah the Exalted said: <<الله لا إِلهَ إِلَّا هُوَ>> (Allah, there is no god except Him). He only negated Divinity (al-ulūhiyya) from being an attribute of more than one. Thus, the Divine Names, or the rank which is the rank of the Named as God (Ilāh), have the disposal (al-taṣrīf) and the judgment over those described by them. By them He disposes, and for them He disposes, yet He is independent of the worlds (ghanī ‘an al-‘ālamīn) in the state of His disposal, which is necessary. Look at how marvelous the matter is in itself. From here, the saying of Abū Sa‘īd al-Kharrāz is understood: that Allah is only known by combining the two opposites (al-ḍiddayn). Then he recited: <<هُوَ الْأَوَّلُ والْآخِرُ والظَّاهِرُ والْباطِنُ>> (He is the First and the Last, the Manifest and the Hidden).

As for the saying of the Jews concerning stinginess: <<يَدُ الله مَغْلُولَةٌ>> (The Hand of Allah is chained), He said concerning them: <<غُلَّتْ أَيْدِيهِمْ ولُعِنُوا بِما قالُوا>> (May their hands be chained, and may they be cursed for what they said). That is, they were distanced from the attribute of Divine Generosity (al-karam al-ilāhī). Their sayings are part of their actions, so their hands were chained, and the stinginess they attributed to Allah occurred through them. Thus, they witnessed nothing from Allah except what they said. Then He made them taste the flavor of what they brought forth. After that, Allah refuted them concerning wealth, for He extended Generosity (al-karam) upon them through the Mercy that <<وَسِعَتْ كُلَّ شَيْءٍ>> (encompassed everything), so that He might make them know that they were liars. This is the most severe torment for them and the most intense bliss. For when He extends bounty and generosity upon them, they realize their ignorance and imagine it. Their souls are tormented by the visualization of the state of ignorance concerning Allah that they were upon, yet they are blessed by the removal of that and their attainment of knowledge. They knew that their ignorance led them to lie against Allah the Exalted: <<بَلْ يَداهُ مَبْسُوطَتانِ يُنْفِقُ كَيْفَ يَشاءُ>> (Rather, His hands are outstretched; He spends as He wills). Thus, the judgment belongs to the Will (al-mashī’a). Understand this. His Will is not other than His Essence. His Names are His Essence, and their judgments are His judgment. The world only appeared through the powers (al-quwā) upon which they rest.

Look to Him, and you will be Him, and do not transgress your limit.
For everything that is in Him is only with you.
Whoever estimates Allah with His true estimation, the reality of Existence (al-wujūd) is manifested from him.
Every matter you see is an essence, and whoever has knowledge of it, it is from Him.
So its essence is the essence of whom you see, and thus Existence has no quiddity (kunh).

If you say "Allah," it is the totality of all Divine Names (al-asmā’ al-ilāhiyya). It is impossible to speak of Him in absolute terms; the states must qualify Him. If words qualify Him, it is by way of dependence on the states. Whatever is attributed to Him, look at which Name that attribution deserves. The Name sought from Allah in that matter is only the Name specialized by that attribution and the Divine Reality (al-ḥaqīqa al-ilāhiyya) that seeks it. Do not transgress it. Whoever is in this state has fulfilled the right of Allah and estimated His estimation in a general sense, for His estimation cannot be estimated in detail, because the increase in the knowledge of Allah (al-‘ilm bi-llāh) never ceases, neither in this world nor the Hereafter. The matter in this regard is infinite.

Do you not see that Allah the Exalted sent Moses (peace be upon him) with a message to Pharaoh, part of which was that if Pharaoh asked him: <<فَما بالُ الْقُرُونِ الْأُولى‏>> (Then what is the state of the former generations?), he should say: <<عِلْمُها عِنْدَ رَبِّي في كِتابٍ لا يَضِلُّ رَبِّي ولا يَنْسى‏>> (The knowledge thereof is with my Lord in a Book. My Lord neither errs [yaḍillu] nor forgets [yansā]). This means what He made incumbent upon Himself concerning that. He only wrote it in the Preserved Tablet (al-Lawḥ al-Maḥfūẓ) so that he whose nature is not to know except by being informed might know, not so that He might remember what He made incumbent upon Himself concerning future times over long periods. For He (Glorified is He) is the Lord who neither errs (yaḍillu) nor forgets (yansā)—the Lord from whom I came to call you to His worship.

The Exalted said concerning Himself: <<نَسُوا الله فَنَسِيَهُمْ>> (They forgot Allah, so He forgot them). They did not forget Him absolutely, so He does not forget them absolutely. Rather, He forgets them concerning that in which they forgot Him, which, had they known it, Mercy (al-raḥma) from the Merciful (al-Raḥīm) concerning that would have reached them. When they forgot it, the Merciful forgot them, since the Divine Name that called for the action they were engaged in took charge of them. When the balance of that Name's justice was fulfilled, the forgetting ceased, for it must cease upon the removal of the veil (kashf al-ghiṭā’) at death in this world. No one among the people of obligation (ahl al-taklīf) dies except as a believer, based on certain knowledge and verified witnessing (al-yaqīn al-muḥaqqaq), without doubt or uncertainty, specifically concerning the knowledge of Allah and faith in Him. This is what is universal. The only question remaining is whether that faith will benefit them or not. As for the lifting of punishment from them, no, except for those whom Allah singles out, such as His saying: <<فَلَمْ يَكُ يَنْفَعُهُمْ إِيمانُهُمْ لَمَّا رَأَوْا بَأْسَنا>> (Their faith was not to benefit them when they saw Our punishment). Then He said—and this is our point of evidence—<<سُنَّتَ الله الَّتِي قَدْ خَلَتْ في عِبادِهِ>> (This is the way [sunna] of Allah which has passed concerning His servants). As for the exception, it is His saying: <<إِلَّا قَوْمَ يُونُسَ لَمَّا آمَنُوا كَشَفْنا عَنْهُمْ عَذابَ الْخِزْيِ في الْحَياةِ الدُّنْيا ومَتَّعْناهُمْ إِلى‏ حِينٍ>> (Except the people of Jonah; when they believed, We removed from them the punishment of disgrace in the life of this world and gave them enjoyment for a time). There is no judgment over Allah concerning His creation. As for the benefit of that faith in the end, your Lord is <<فَعَّالٌ لِما يُرِيدُ>> (Doer of what He intends). And He (Exalted is He) says: <<إِنَّ الله يَغْفِرُ الذُّنُوبَ جَمِيعاً>> (Indeed, Allah forgives all sins). This is His word, His covenant to us in His Book and upon the tongues of His Messengers (peace be upon them).

The Real has appeared in what a Messenger brought to my heart from the Highest Assembly (al-Mala’ al-A‘lā).
He informed me of the matter from its half, so I do not say "more likely" or "more worthy" concerning matters.
Rather, the matter in it is one and nothing else: from a world that perishes, and from a world that perishes.
And that is a Criterion (furqān) whose proof is made clear, and it is not a Qur’an recited upon our heart.
Even though the Word of Allah, in every state, is dictated to me when I come to His Presence (ḥaḍra).
And my creation is wondrous, constantly renewed, and what has passed of it neither ceases nor perishes.
The judgment of the Wise Real (al-Ḥakīm al-Ḥaqq) is manifest in creation. Glory be to Him who blinds, and Glory be to Him who clarifies.
He has been generous to me with His grace through His witnessing (shuhūd), and He has singled me out with the sweetest source of it.

Whoever fears Allah, He grants him a Criterion (furqān), even though it is in the essence of the Glorious Qur’an (al-Qur’ān al-‘Azīz), which is the gathering (al-jam‘)—just as you gather water in a basin when you collect it. Not every criterion is a Qur’an, but every Qur’an is a criterion.

The essence of Gathering (al-jam‘) is the essence of Separation (al-farq). So look with your eye at the union in separation.
The like is not the essence of the like, so judge concerning it with separation and with meeting.
And if we wish, when you reflect upon it, we judge by marriage (al-nikāḥ) and by divorce (al-ṭalāq).
Were it not for the Real, there would be no coherence (ittisāq). So the leg of the Real is wrapped around my leg.
When we stray from Him, He calls me, so that I may know that in the Hereafter is my destination.
To Him, in bodies made of plants. If we are good, then musk in caskets.

<<فَرِيقٌ في الْجَنَّةِ وفَرِيقٌ في السَّعِيرِ>> (A party in Paradise and a party in the Blazing Fire). The one who doubled himself is distinguished from the one who doubled him. Each party is singled out by its oneness (aḥadiyya) and its collectivity (jam‘iyya). Among them are those who find intimacy (ta’annasa) in their singularity through their oneness and individuality, and among them are those who feel alienation (istaḥwasha) in their singularity through their oneness and individuality. That, according to the Gnostics (al-‘ārifīn), is the alienation of the Veil (waḥshat al-ḥijāb).

What bliss is there that Time (al-dahr) does not disturb? And to Allah belongs the creation (al-khalq) and the command (al-amr) in what I have said.
Were it not for the Existence of the Real (wujūd al-Ḥaqq), His good would not be; and were it not for my existence, evil (al-sharr) would not be seen among creatures.
I am not other than Him, if my reality were revealed, but He concealed, so my affair is a veil for Him.
Whoever realizes my image, for him, the pearl and the pearl (al-durr wa-l-durr) shine forth from my genesis.
A pearl, not stones, competes with my genesis, and for knowledge, the pearl grants what it grants from them.
If you possess intellect (‘aql), its judgment will be clear; and if you possess the eye (‘ayn), the veil (al-sitr) has been lifted.
If you wish, point to it as sealed nectar (raḥīqan makhtūman); and if you do not wish wine (khamr), then your drink is beer (al-mizr).
Glory be to Him who revives the heart (al-fu’ād) with His remembrance (dhikr), and were there no remembrance, reflection (al-fikr) would stand in its place.

[The Fixity of Knowledge upon its Image]

Know, may Allah support you with a spirit from Him, that I have not seen the Fixity of Knowledge (thubūt al-‘ilm) upon its image, unchanging, except in this station (manzil). It bequeathed to me the tranquility (al-ṭuma’nīna) that what I know will not vanish, and that doubts (al-shubah) will not shake it. If a doubt comes to one who witnesses this matter in this station, he sees it as a doubt that cannot change its image for him. This is unlike one who does not possess this station, for he is shaken, and that shaking leads him to examine what he had previously determined he knew. He does not know whether the first knowledge was a doubt, or whether the witnessing (al-shuhūd) is a doubt, or whether both matters are doubts, so he becomes bewildered. This is because he is not upon clear insight (baṣīra) in his knowledge of matters, for he generated them by his reflection (fikr). When matters come by themselves, not by your making or creation, they grant you their realities (ḥaqā’iq), and you know them as they truly are.

Many verses from the Glorious Qur’an (al-Qur’ān al-‘Azīz) relate to this station. If we were to elaborate on them, the discussion would be lengthy. We shall mention some, but not all, and I will not explain them, but only point them out for sound intellects and penetrating insights. Among them are: <<ولِلَّهِ مُلْكُ السَّماواتِ والْأَرْضِ>> (And to Allah belongs the dominion of the heavens and the earth). And: <<لَهُ الْمُلْكُ ولَهُ الْحَمْدُ وهُوَ عَلى‏ كُلِّ شَيْءٍ قَدِيرٌ>> (To Him belongs the dominion, and to Him belongs the praise, and He is over all things competent) in Sūrat al-Taghābun. And: <<وقالَتِ امْرَأَتُ فِرْعَوْنَ قُرَّتُ عَيْنٍ لِي ولَكَ>> (And the wife of Pharaoh said, "[He will be] a comfort of the eye for me and for you"). And: <<وَيْلٌ لِلْمُطَفِّفِينَ>> (Woe to those who give less than due). And: <<فَوَيْلٌ لِلْمُصَلِّينَ>> (So woe to those who pray). And: <<فَوَيْلٌ يَوْمَئِذٍ لِلْمُكَذِّبِينَ>> (So woe, that Day, to the deniers), wherever it occurs. And: <<وتَاللَّهِ لَأَكِيدَنَّ أَصْنامَكُمْ بَعْدَ أَنْ تُوَلُّوا مُدْبِرِينَ>> (And by Allah, I will surely plot against your idols after you have turned your backs and gone away). And: <<ولَئِنْ سَأَلْتَهُمْ من خَلَقَهُمْ لَيَقُولُنَّ الله>> (And if you asked them who created them, they would surely say, "Allah")—a preparation for their felicity. And: <<لِلَّهِ الْأَمْرُ من قَبْلُ ومن بَعْدُ>> (To Allah belongs the command before and after). This verse begins [the chapter] so that it may be known what the Command is upon, in relation to Him. And: <<إِنَّ رَبَّهُمْ بِهِمْ يَوْمَئِذٍ لَخَبِيرٌ>> (Indeed, their Lord is, concerning them, that Day, All-Aware [khabīr]). He sufficed with awareness (khibra) instead of knowledge (‘ilm), since every awareness is knowledge. And: <<ولَوْ شاءَ الله لَجَمَعَهُمْ عَلَى الْهُدى‏>> (And if Allah had willed, He could have gathered them upon guidance). He used the particle of refusal for refusal (ḥarf imtinā‘ li-mtinā‘). And: <<ولَوْ لا أَنْ يَكُونَ النَّاسُ أُمَّةً واحِدَةً لَجَعَلْنا لِمَنْ يَكْفُرُ بِالرَّحْمنِ لِبُيُوتِهِمْ سُقُفاً من فِضَّةٍ ومَعارِجَ عَلَيْها يَظْهَرُونَ>> (And were it not that the people would become one community [in disbelief], We would have made for those who disbelieve in the Most Merciful, for their houses, roofs of silver and stairways upon which they ascend). And: <<إِنَّ السَّاعَةَ آتِيَةٌ أَكادُ أُخْفِيها لِتُجْزى‏ كُلُّ نَفْسٍ بِما تَسْعى‏>> (Indeed, the Hour is coming—I almost conceal it—so that every soul may be recompensed for what it strives). And: <<وَكَذلِكَ فَتَنَّا بَعْضَهُمْ بِبَعْضٍ لِيَقُولُوا أَ هؤُلاءِ من الله عَلَيْهِمْ من بَيْنِنا>> (And thus We have tried some of them by others, so that they might say, "Are these the ones whom Allah has favored among us?"). And: <<ما كانَ الله لِيَذَرَ الْمُؤْمِنِينَ عَلى‏ ما أَنْتُمْ عَلَيْهِ>> (Allah would not leave the believers upon the state in which you are), and the rest of the verse. And: <<ثُمَّ لْيَقْضُوا تَفَثَهُمْ ولْيُوفُوا نُذُورَهُمْ ولْيَطَّوَّفُوا بِالْبَيْتِ الْعَتِيقِ>> (Then let them end their untidiness and fulfill their vows and perform circumambulation around the Ancient House). And: <<لَتُؤْمِنُنَّ به ولَتَنْصُرُنَّهُ>> (You will surely believe in him and you will surely support him). And: <<وقُلِ الْحَقُّ من رَبِّكُمْ فَمَنْ شاءَ فَلْيُؤْمِنْ ومن شاءَ فَلْيَكْفُرْ>> (And say, "The truth is from your Lord," so whoever wills—let him believe; and whoever wills—let him disbelieve), and the rest of the verse. And: <<وإِنَّهُ لِحُبِّ الْخَيْرِ لَشَدِيدٌ>> (And indeed, he is severe in the love of wealth [al-khayr]). And: <<يَوْمَئِذٍ تُحَدِّثُ أَخْبارَها بِأَنَّ رَبَّكَ أَوْحى‏ لَها>> (That Day, it will report its news because your Lord has inspired it). And: <<أَ فَمَنْ يَمْشِي مُكِبًّا عَلى‏ وَجْهِهِ أَهْدى‏>> (Then is he who walks headlong upon his face more rightly guided?)—and this is he who falls upon his face into the Fire from the Bridge (al-Ṣirāṭ), yet he is one of the monotheists (al-muwaḥḥidīn). And: <<وهُوَ الَّذِي يُنَزِّلُ الْغَيْثَ من بَعْدِ ما قَنَطُوا ويَنْشُرُ رَحْمَتَهُ>> (And He is the one who sends down the rain after they have despaired and spreads His Mercy). And: <<إِنَّ في ذلِكَ لَعِبْرَةً لِأُولِي الْأَبْصارِ>> (Indeed, in that is a lesson [‘ibra] for those of insight)—meaning, a wonder. And: <<فَمَنْ يَكْفُرْ بَعْدُ مِنْكُمْ فَإِنِّي أُعَذِّبُهُ عَذاباً لا أُعَذِّبُهُ أَحَداً من الْعالَمِينَ>> (So whoever disbelieves after that among you, I will surely punish him with a punishment that I will not punish anyone among the worlds). And: <<وهُوَ مَعَكُمْ أَيْنَ ما كُنْتُمْ>> (And He is with you wherever you are).

Reflect upon the stations of these verses and their likes. From here, you know the power of the *alif* and *lām* (ال) which denote definition, specification, and genus, and the attachment of *lām-alif* (لا) to the letters. The letters are of two types: letters of the alphabet (ḥurūf hijā’), which are the original letters, and letters of meaning (ḥurūf ma‘ānī). Both are in the written form by convention and in the utterance by nature in the human. All of it is from you and in you. There is no matter outside of you. So do not hope to know yourself by other than yourself, for there is nothing there. You are the proof for yourself and for Him, and there is no one who is a proof for you.

Who is it you hope for besides yourself, when you are alone in both states?
Look to Him by Him, and you will be Him, for everything that is in Him is with you.

In this station are sciences: the science of the judgments that causes (al-asbāb) have in the effects (al-musabbabāt), and the detailed explanation of the causes, and whether the entire world is causes for one another, and whether some causes are non-existent (adam) yet are a means (sabab), such as proportions (al-nisab)—like the connections of meanings that necessitate judgments by their connection. In it is the science of what is established for Allah of judgments, rationally and legally. In it is the science of the benefit of news (al-akhbār) in the intelligible object of information (al-mukhayyar al-ma‘qūl), and which news provides certain knowledge, which provides conjecture (ẓann) or dominant conjecture (ghalabat ẓann), which news provides bewilderment (ḥayra), and which news impugns theoretical proofs (al-adilla al-naẓariyya) by impugning knowledge.

In it is the science of whether the creation being the dependents of Allah (iyāl Allāh) means the same as: <<يا أَيُّهَا النَّاسُ أَنْتُمُ الْفُقَراءُ إِلَى الله>> (O mankind, you are the needy [al-fuqarā’] toward Allah). And in what respect is the poverty (al-faqr) when they are existent and know from the Real that they will not cease to exist after their existence? Rather, it is a revolution of states upon them: a state that vanishes and a state that comes. The vanishing state grants a judgment by its vanishing, and the coming state grants a judgment by its coming. The entity (al-‘ayn) upon which the two judgments are passed is one, like the standing person who sits. Sitting is coming, and standing is vanishing. The judgment of the vanishing of standing is that he is not standing, which is the essence of the judgment of sitting. Sitting adds judgments to him that were not understood from the vanishing of standing, which he has now attained: that he is neither reclining, nor bowing, nor prostrating, nor lying prone.

In it is the science of the wisdom of questioning the knowledgeable person about what he knows. In it is the science of why what the sight perceives of the transformation of the single essence (al-‘ayn al-wāḥida) into images, in the view of the observer, returns to: Is it in itself as the sight perceives it, or is it as it is in itself, its essence having not changed? This returns to what is seen of the essences (al-a‘yān) and judged to be essences: Did they multiply by accidents (‘arāḍ) or by substances (jawāhir)? For the images constantly differ in perception. Every object seen by the eye among bodies is a body. Corporeality (al-jismīyya) is a general judgment, and we see different images in it, some of which vanish quickly, and some slowly in perception. The body is a body; it has not changed. The body is the only thing described by what appeared. Likewise are the spiritual images (al-ṣuwar al-rūḥāniyya) and the Divine Theophany (al-tajallī al-ilāhī). This is a science involving a great difficulty, and escaping it through theoretical reflection (al-naẓar al-fikrī) is extremely hard.

In it is the science of the conditions that the deputy (al-nā’ib) may stipulate upon the one who appointed him (al-mustakhlaf), despite the deputy's knowledge that he is compelled (maqhūr) in his appointment. Does his stipulation indicate his ignorance of the one who appointed him, or his forgetfulness, so that he reminds him, or does he know his interests better than the one who appointed him? In this stipulation, terrifying matters open up that impugn [the appointment]. Or does the deputy know that the one who appointed him wants him to ask him concerning what he stipulated, so that He may show him his need (faqr) for Him through spiritual taste (dhawq)? For if the deputy had independence (al-istiqlāl) concerning what he requested in his condition, he would not have stipulated it.

In it is the science of the deputy offering a bribe (al-rishā’) to the one who appointed him, and what kind of bribe is acceptable and what is not. In it is the science of the appointer answering the deputy in everything he asks concerning his interests. In it is the science that criticizing the employed (al-mustakhdamīn) is a disparagement of the one who employed them. This is a very dangerous science. For this reason, criticism of kings and caliphs is forbidden, and we are informed that their hearts are in the Hand of Allah; if He wills, He contracts them away from us, and if He wills, He inclines them toward us. We are commanded to pray for them. The occurrence of benefit through them for the general populace is greater than their tyranny (jawr). What is the wisdom of their tyranny, despite their being truly the deputies of Allah over His creation, whether they are disbelievers or believers, just or tyrannical? This does not remove the designation of deputyship (al-niyāba) from them. If the deputy is tyrannical, is he dismissed from the deputyship only in that specific act of tyranny, or is he dismissed from the deputyship absolutely, and then the Real renews another, renewed deputyship for him?

In it is the science of counting blessings (al-ni‘am) by the Bestower upon the recipient: Is this a disparagement? Or is it a definition so that the recipient may know the measure of that blessing, for which he is required to give thanks? Or is it a punishment for something that occurred from them? Or is it permissible to include all these aspects together? In it is the science of gentleness in teaching in some situations, and harshness in others. In it is the science of where you came from and where you are going. Is there truly a return (rujū‘), or is it an eternal journey (sulūk abadan qadam) with no return? And to what Divine proportion does the return of the intelligible and the sensible in the world relate? Is the Real described by return in the way we described return, or not? For the Realities (al-ḥaqā’iq) refuse that there be a return. In it is the science of the difference between describing the speaking souls (al-nufūs al-nāṭiqa) with intellects (‘uqūl), prohibitions (nahy), judgments (aḥkām), hearts (albāb), and similar titles—to what does this return?

In it is the science of the wisdom of establishing a proof (dalīl) for one who does not know that it is a proof, while knowing that he is knowledgeable in this attribute. Is he himself intended by that proof, or is it someone else, so that he becomes a transmitter (nāqil) in it, and thus benefits and accepts it from those to whom the transmission of this person who did not know it was a proof reaches? This happens often, and it is the saying of the Prophet (peace and blessings be upon him): "Perhaps the carrier of jurisprudence (fiqh) is not a jurist (faqīh)." If he carries it and transmits it to a jurist, that jurist accepts it and benefits from it with knowledge he did not possess, while the transmitter has no knowledge of any of that.

In it is the science of naming a thing by the name of another thing if it is adjacent to it or if it is a cause of it. In it is the science of why the Lawgiver commanded the killing of the sorcerer (al-sāḥir), and why he was named a disbeliever (kāfir). Since Pharaoh knew the truthfulness of Moses (peace be upon him) and concealed faith in his soul, which he manifested when he drowned upon seeing the punishment (al-ba’s), was the killing of the sorcerers who believed due to their being sorcerers, so that their killing was legally justified in the inner reality (bāṭin al-amr), and due to their faith in the outer reality (ẓāhir al-amr)? If the sorcerer is killed, is that killing an expiation for him and a recompense for his sorcery, such that no claim remains against him concerning that sorcery in the Hereafter from the Real (Glorified and Exalted is He), or is there no claim against him from Allah?

In it is the science of the preference (tafāḍul) of those brought near (al-muqarrabīn) to Allah: by what are some preferred over others? In it is the science of the saying of the Prophet (peace and blessings be upon him) concerning the affliction of the believer with calamities and misfortunes (al-razāyā wa-l-maṣā’ib): that there is good for him in all of that. Why are the People of Allah (ahl Allāh) in this world afflicted with greater tribulation than others? And to what does the necessity of that return in their case, as opposed to other believing people?

In it is the science of why souls are naturally inclined to love wealth (al-māl), especially gold: Is it because of its attainment of the degree of mineral perfection (al-kamāl al-ma‘danī), leading to a correspondence between the two perfect ones? Or is it because it fulfills their needs, so they are poor toward it for reaching their goals? And the saying of Jesus (peace be upon him): "The heart of every person is where his wealth is, so place your wealth in heaven, and your hearts will be in heaven." Whoever hoards his wealth has buried his heart in the earth of his nature, and thus will never enjoy the witnessing (mushāhada) of his Father, who is the Divine Spirit (al-Rūḥ al-Ilāhī). Such a person is the son of his mother, even if he has a father, but he is not attributed to him, like Jesus son of Mary (peace be upon him), who is attributed to his mother. Yet, Gabriel (peace be upon him) only bestowed him upon her when he appeared to her as <<بَشَراً سَوِيًّا>> (a man in all respects) and informed her. Despite this, he is only attributed to the physical location (al-buq‘a al-jismīyya), even though he revives the dead by virtue of his being from the gifts of the Trustworthy Spirit (al-Rūḥ al-Amīn).

In it is the science of the Divine Jealousy (الغيرة الإلهية) and against whom He is jealous concerning the specific Name by which He honored him. In it is the science of when the answer to the petitioner is determined concerning what he asked, if he asked. And if one asks by state (bi-l-ḥāl), is his answer determined by state, such that the answer corresponds to the question?

In it is the science of the abasement of him who elevates himself and the degradation of him who overreaches his measure. In it is the science of the benefit of admonition (al-maw‘iẓa), even if one disbelieves in it, for it has an effect in the inner being (al-bāṭin) of the listener, even if it does not appear; he senses it within himself. In it is the science of him who intended a deception (kayd) but encountered a truth (ḥaqq), which he considered a lie, but the outcome revealed that it was true in reality, though he has no knowledge of that. In it is the science of times (al-awqāt) and how they are dealt with, rationally and legally, according to sound reflection. In it is the science of defining noble character (makārim al-akhlāq). In it is the science that knowledge of what is not known to be known is [still] knowledge. And Allah <<يَقُولُ الْحَقَّ وهُوَ يَهْدِي السَّبِيلَ>> (speaks the Truth, and He guides to the Way).
